internal.content:
---
title: Website Monitoring
description: None
---

<PageDescription>

In this part of the the lab you will learn how Instana can be used to monitor websites, which is often called end-user monitoring.

</PageDescription>

## Website Montoring

Got to the **WebSites & Mobile Apps** perspective in the Instana UI.

Select the website called **Robot Shop**, which we have already created for you. Look at the configuration tab to see the details.

For website monitoring a tracking script has to be integrated in your website, to track browser requests. The request information is send to an instana reporting URL, usind a unique key.
The robot-shop application that you deployed into your Kubernetes cluster has this script already included, so nothing to do on the application site for you.

<InlineNotification kind="info">

**Note:** When deploying the robot-shop application you allready specified the values:

- eum.key
- eum.url

Which correspond to the reportingURL and the required key. 

</InlineNotification>

If not still open, open a new borwser tab and enter the application URL for **Stan's Robot Shop** and browse the application. E.g. order some nice 
```
export CLUSTER_ID=$(ibmcloud ks cluster ls | grep lab2220 | awk '{print $2}')
NODEPORT=$(kubectl get -o jsonpath="{.spec.ports[0].nodePort}" service web)
URL=$(ibmcloud ks cluster get --cluster $CLUSTER_ID --show-resources | grep "Ingress Subdomain" | awk '{print $NF}')
echo "http://$URL:$NODEPORT"
```

Click arround for some time, maybe order the artificial intelligence **STAN** or reload the base URL of the application.

Go back to the Instana UI, ensure that you selected **Live** to get actual updated into the view.
![instana-website-summary](./images/instana-website-summary.png)

Look at the different tabs
* Summary
* Speed
* Resources
* HTTP Requests
* JS Errors (should be empty ;-)
* Geography - maybe switch to the 3D view
* Custom Events - empty
* Pages
* Alerts - hopefully also empty

Go back to the **HTTP Requests** Tab and click on the origin for your cluster

To analyse a specific call end to end, click on on of the bars in the call windows and select `View in Analyse`
![instana-website-httprequests](./images/instana-website-httprequests.png)

Open the Call group `/api/catalogue/categories`and click on one of the get GET requests
![instana-analyse-httprequestgroup](./images/instana-analyse-httprequestgroup.png)

You will be preseted with the different activities in request. To view what gets executed on the backend of the application for this request, click `View Backend Trace`.
![instana-analyse-requesttype](./images/instana-analyse-requesttype.png)

Scroll down to the Calls Section to see the details of the call and the time spend in the sub calls. 
![instana-analyse-backendtrace](./images/instana-analyse-backendtrace.png)

Congratulations you have sucessfully observed a request end to end from the browser to a database.

MdxNode.rawBody:

title: Website Monitoring
description: None
---

<PageDescription>

In this part of the the lab you will learn how Instana can be used to monitor websites, which is often called end-user monitoring.

## Website Montoring

For website monitoring a tracking script has to be integrated in your website, to track browser requests. The request information is send to an instana reporting URL, usind a unique key.
The robot-shop application that you deployed into your Kubernetes cluster has this script already included, so nothing to do on the application site for you.

<InlineNotification kind="info">

**Note:** When deploying the robot-shop application you allready specified the values:

- eum.key
- eum.url

Which correspond to the reportingURL and the required key. 

</InlineNotification>

If not still open, open a new borwser tab and enter the application URL for **Stan's Robot Shop** and browse the application. E.g. order some nice 
```
export CLUSTER_ID=$(ibmcloud ks cluster ls | grep lab2220 | awk '{print $2}')

URL=$(ibmcloud ks cluster get --cluster $CLUSTER_ID --show-resources | grep "Ingress Subdomain" | awk '{print $NF}')
```

![instana-website-summary](./images/instana-website-summary.png)

Look at the different tabs

* Speed
* Resources
* HTTP Requests
* JS Errors (should be empty ;-)
* Geography - maybe switch to the 3D view

![instana-analyse-backendtrace](./images/instana-analyse-backendtrace.png)

Congratulations you have sucessfully observed a request end to end from the browser to a database.
